The correct answer for this problem would be:

BT x BT -> 3/4 BT; 1/4 Bb (where b = blue)

Explanation:
If we have a monohybrid cross between two heterozygous parents (one carrying BT and the other carrying Bb), then according to Mendel's laws of segregation, there will be three different gametes formed from these parents: BT, Bb, and bt. When these gametes are combined during fertilization, we can end up with four different genotypic combinations: BT (dominant homozygote), Bb (heterozygote), Bt (recessive homozygote), or any combination where both dominant alleles combine together. Since dominant traits mask recessive ones, only the first three possibilities matter for our purposes here. We know that in the F1 generation, the ratio of phenotypes observed was 3 blue : 1 green plants, so assuming that all plants that appear blue have either BT or Bb genotype, while all plants appearing green must carry at least one copy of bt. Therefore, we can conclude that among the 75% of blue plants, half of them must actually possess the Bb heterozygote genotype, since they may have inherited either paternal BT or maternal Bb allele. That means that the remaining 50% of the blue plants represent purebred dominant homozygotes (i.e., those that received both copies of BT from their parents). Hence, out of 8 possible genetic outcomes, we ended up with 4 viable ones in the F1 generation, i.e., 3 BT:1 Bb. However, it should be noted again that this result assumes
